instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SDA: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SDA? SMBUS_CHGR_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SCL: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SCL? SMBUS_CHGR_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hello
Have a 3462 that doesn't power up. Only corrosion found was on <CAPACITOR>C1683</CAPACITOR> positive pad. Resistance is about 4ohms. Also MagSafe adaptor light isn't coming on. I've tried SMC bypass and it still doesn't boot. Below are measurements taken:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.3
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 12.3
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> - 12.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>- 3.4
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL> - 0

Any suggestion?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So liquid sign on the CPU area; that's not good at all.
4 ohms could be correct value for VCORE, depending on CPU type; compare with similar board.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.3"
Post diode mode and voltage readings on SCL/SDA lines of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.
Also post resistance between its pins 17/18 and 27/28.

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Post <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> and the 4 RTC signals (page 17).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Sorry for the late response. Here are the readings

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.4 (diode mode: 0.5)
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> - 3.4 (diode mode: 0.5)
pins 17/18 - 4 ohms
pins 27/28 - 22 ohms
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> - 0
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3_PCH</SIGNAL> - 3.4
<SIGNAL>SYSCLK_CLK32K_RTC</SIGNAL> - 32.78kHz square wave

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> - 0"
Looks like SMC issue.
Reball it first and change if no result.
Be sure first all resistors and trace around SMC are good.

"<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL> - 3.4 (diode mode: 0.5)
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> - 3.4 (diode mode: 0.5)"
Try to post relevant informatiuon.
0.510 and 0.520 could be write both as 0.5 but difference on battery bus should be less than 0.5%, think about that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yep, it was the SMC. Replaced the SMC after reballing the original.

Second question: if one of the fans was bad, would this cause the second fan to run high. The system isn't hot. I'm currently waiting on a replacement fan but wanted to make sure it wasn't something else that need fixed as well as replacing the fan. I did confirm that the fan was the issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Run ASD, or use HWMonitor to check temps of the system.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Got this error: 4m0t/4/40000002 right side - 0. Which is the fan i'm assuming.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Please post entire error message from ASD; a picture maybe?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So the AHT gave the above result. So reran using the asd thumb driver version. First test failed on the SMC section. Disabled the SMC test and reran with it then failing on sensor. See pictures.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You could specify Ts0P error from the beggining.
That is trackpad temperature sensor, but the error could be generated by another device connected in the same I2C bus; like ALS, for example.
So disconnect webcam first and also check its connector for corrosion, or bent pins.
Next step, try known good working trackpad board/flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I checked the webcam connector for bent pins or bridged pins, none. I also unplugged everything and swapped the trackpad and cable with the same result. I pulled the board from the frame and check for anything out of the norm, all looks good. The left fan always start up at high speed. The right fan always starts at the normal speed then slowly ramps up to high speed. I've swapped the fan to confirm that it's not the fan that's acting up.

Wondering if the issue is with the SMC? Is there a way to check this?

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_GPUTHMSNS_SDA</SIGNAL> - 33.6Khz
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_GPUTHMSNS_SCL</SIGNAL> - 95.79K
<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SDA</SIGNAL> - 33.6k
<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SCL</SIGNAL> - 98.33K

And each of their pull up's have 3.3V. 

Any other suggestions of signals to check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SDA</SIGNAL> - 33.6k
<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SCL</SIGNAL> - 98.33K"
Always check diode mode (red probe at ground) on data lines; ohm scale only needed after very low diode mode readings.
Did you try known good RIO board/flex?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SDA</SIGNAL> - 0.482
<SIGNAL>I2C_CPUTHMSNS_SCL</SIGNAL> - 0.484

I currently do not have a spare RIO board or flex cable. As i haven't work too much with this version year, won't unplugging the RIO board and cable change the behavior of the board; meaning, won't the fast fan spin right after power up return to the slow ramp up if the issue was with the RIO board? The left fan spins really fast at start up (no ramp), whether everything is connected to the board or not. 

Is it possible the issue is with the SMC that i got?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Could be SMc issue, or just one sensor problem.
Run HWMonitor and see which temp is strange...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: So HWMonitor is saying Heatpipe incoming Air is 128 degrees (see pic). Any idea what sensor this is referring to?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Could be a problem with the airflow temp sensor, or other device connected on <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_1</SIGNAL>.
Check <TRANSISTOR>Q5502</TRANSISTOR>/04 connections to <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Checked <TRANSISTOR>Q5502</TRANSISTOR>/04 connections to <CHIP>U5570</CHIP>.and it was good. So went ahead and replaced the SMC. The board is now fixed. 

thanks for the assist.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Possibly just a bad solder on that bus under SMC.
You can try same SMC in other board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not powering up. Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah i tried the same smc at first with the same result before i then replaced it.
